pullRequest.body:
This lets `IsLocalRingHom` take two monoids instead of rings. Furthermore, it moves lemmas to be available a bit earlier where they are relevant to other theories, and tries to adapt those theories to use them a bit better.

nodes.body: I'd rather not have several deprecated copies of lemmata lying around; I don't think it breaks that much?
My reasoning is that we're talking about three lemmas vs breakage in a few files.
sure but that can apply everywhere; the breakage isn't that big either - I'd rather have lemmas in the "right" form and not have lots of "deprecated" additional forms around

That's the thing. I'm not convinced (anymore) that lemmas stated using hom classes are the panacea. If there are elaboration issues, we should derive special cases in terms of the concrete structures.

The primary goal is usability, not library purity. If your lemmas don't unify properly, add some more.

I've started a thread about this here:

https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/HomClasses.20and.20tooling

I'd love to hear everyone's thoughts.

I like the spirit of this PR in principal. But it's sad that in several places the performance degrades, and that there is a netto increase of number of lines in the diff. I guess you are adding some new material as well as refactoring?

The new lines are mostly adding glue code for combining the `MonoidHomClass` version with the specific `RingHom` version, but I will take a further look now this is merged. The merge was really ugly...
I checked and the new timeouts are still needed even with master merged :/
Yeah, I'm really not sure it's worth slowing proofs down when they were working just fine before. I'm happy with the new lemmas, though.
I don't see why we should stop a big refactor because 3 proofs slowed down - by that logic we shouldn't have ported RingTheory/Kaehler from Lean3!
!bench

nodes.body: Could you reduce the diff/downstream breakage by keeping a `RingHom` version of the lemmas (instead of just having the `MonoidHomClass` one)? This will help unification loads and make this PR much more straightforward to get merged. The cost is only a few duplicated lemmas and we can decide on keeping them vs throwing them away later on.
I'd rather not have several deprecated copies of lemmata lying around; I don't think it breaks that much?
My reasoning is that we're talking about three lemmas vs breakage in a few files.
sure but that can apply everywhere; the breakage isn't that big either - I'd rather have lemmas in the "right" form and not have lots of "deprecated" additional forms around

That's the thing. I'm not convinced (anymore) that lemmas stated using hom classes are the panacea. If there are elaboration issues, we should derive special cases in terms of the concrete structures.

The primary goal is usability, not library purity. If your lemmas don't unify properly, add some more.

I've started a thread about this here:

https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/HomClasses.20and.20tooling

I'd love to hear everyone's thoughts.

I like the spirit of this PR in principal. But it's sad that in several places the performance degrades, and that there is a netto increase of number of lines in the diff. I guess you are adding some new material as well as refactoring?

The new lines are mostly adding glue code for combining the `MonoidHomClass` version with the specific `RingHom` version, but I will take a further look now this is merged. The merge was really ugly...
I checked and the new timeouts are still needed even with master merged :/
Yeah, I'm really not sure it's worth slowing proofs down when they were working just fine before. I'm happy with the new lemmas, though.
I don't see why we should stop a big refactor because 3 proofs slowed down - by that logic we shouldn't have ported RingTheory/Kaehler from Lean3!

I further removed the requirement of `F` being a `MonoidHomClass` in the definition of `IsLocalHom`. But all meaningful lemmas are developed with the condition `MonoidHomClass F M N`

One problem I met is that there is no `FunLike (M → N) M N` instance, so it is not possible to speak `IsLocalHom f` when `(f : M → N)`. But I don't think this is a serious issue since we only use this notation for `[MonoidHomClass F M N] (f : F)`
In order to split the PR into smaller pieces, I will open another PR only to rename `IsLocalRingHom` to `IsLocalHom`. See #17403
